title: I keep coming up with different story ideas when I'm working on my current story. They can be somewhat distracting. What should I do? - Quora

response.answer_text: A lot of writers self-sabotage when their WIP (work in progress) gets difficult. Yes, you can ignore those ideas, but really what you need to do is pay attention. This is your subconscious talking, and sometimes your subconscious is smarter than you might expect. Has your story taken a dull, predictable turn? What if the new story idea is in fact an abstract suggestion for a better course to take? For example, I’ve been working on a story that’s getting pretty abstract and symbolic, and I’ve been worrying that it’s so far out there that the reader won’t be able to connect. My brain starts thinking about the new S&S series I plan on writing when I’m done with this trilogy. What’s the appeal of the new S&S story? It’s down-to-earth, gritty, immediate. My WIP is getting all spiritual on my ass. So, maybe I should take a hint from my subconscious and bring some aspect of my WIP back down into the real world. Maybe I should jerk my character from the spiritual world back to reality, which will endanger everyone and make it that much harder to return and solve the spiritual problem he’s facing. These new ideas may relate more to your WIP than you realize. Examine them as if they’re dreams, and you’re a psychiatrist analyzing them and relating them to the patient’s real world problems. You may end up with a breakthrough that will help you finish your WIP. Good luck!

Get the supplementary ideas out of your system by writing precis and filing them for future reference. The more, the merrier. Review these items say, weekly - you may find that some of them are relevant to your original project and can be incorporated. If you were to do this regularly, you may well have a file of very useful ideas for future projects.
